This study investigates the molecular dynamics of methane dry reforming catalyzed by a novel nickel-strontium-zirconium-aluminum (5Ni+3Sr/10Zr+Al) catalyst, leveraging both Response Surface Methodology (RSM) and Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN) for predictive optimization. Focusing on the impact of operational parameters—hourly space velocity, reaction temperature, and CO2:CH4 mole ratio—on the conversion rates and formation of reaction components, we aim to predict optimal conditions and corresponding process variables. Through a comparison of a three-layer Feed Forward Neural Network, optimized at a 3:10:1 topology, with traditional RSM approaches, our findings highlight the superior predictive capabilities of ANN models. Notably, ANN demonstrated exceptional performance with R adj 2 and F_Ratio values significantly surpass those of RSM, alongside lower statistical error terms. This superiority is attributed to ANN's robust handling of nonlinear relationships between inputs and outputs, asserting its potential for enhancing predictive accuracy in chemical process optimization. At optimum predicted conditions like 1 CH4/CO2,750 °C reaction temperature, 12000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity, NiSrZrAl outperformed with > 85 % CH4 and CO2 conversion with H2/CO ∼1 up to 20 h time on stream. Our research underscores the importance of integrating advanced modeling techniques for the efficient and accurate prediction of catalytic reactions, offering valuable insights for future applications in chemical engineering and catalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Methane dry reforming Response surface methodology Artificial neural network Radial basis function Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The intensive exploitation of fossil resources, pivotal to humanity's development, has led to a dramatic increase in atmospheric CO2 emissions—from 228 ppm in the pre-industrial era to 424.55 ppm in February 2024 (NOAA Global Monitoring Laboratory (.gov). This surge exerts significant pressure on human survival, highlighting carbon dioxide as the primary greenhouse gas driving human-induced climate change. In response, various strategies for CO2 emission reduction and control have been explored, focusing on carbon capture and storage (CCS) or its utilization (CCU). Notably, converting captured CO2 into fuels, using green hydrogen produced through the electrolysis of water powered by renewable energy sources, not only mitigates atmospheric CO2 levels but also offers a means to store excess renewable energy efficiently. Among various techniques for CO2 conversion, the dry reforming of methane (DRM) has garnered considerable attention. This process, capable of transforming two potent greenhouse gases—methane (CH4) and CO2—into valuable syngas (H2 and CO) with a near-ideal H2:CO ratio for synthesizing liquid hydrocarbons, fuels, and chemicals, represents a promising avenue for leveraging excess methane, particularly from low-quality natural gas and biogas sources rich in CO2 [1–4]. The relevant reaction scheme for DRM reaction can be presented as the dissociation of CH4 over edge-step sites of Ni followed by oxidation of dissociated (CH4-x; x = 1–4) by CO2 [5,6] (Fig. 1 ). Ni supported over conventional support Al2O3 has certain catalytic limitation for DRM reaction that is diffusion of active sites “Ni” into alumina lattice. This issue was mitigated by incorporating a small amount of ZrO2 into the Al2O3 support, which prevents the diffusion of nickel [7]. The zirconia-alumina support also benefited from oxygen endowing capacity of zirconia. Alkali metal oxide (Ba, Ca, Mg) promoted DRM catalyst was found to enhance the CO2 interaction over the surface [8]. Calcium addition into Ni/ZrO2 also showed stabilization of the tetragonal phase of zirconia [9], whereas MgO addition in Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZrO2 resulted in enhanced metal support interaction and optimization of the size of active sites [10,11]. Recently, strontium addition as a promotor was found to enhance Sr+2 mediated CO2 interaction, surface oxide enrichment and generation of smaller crystallite in DRM [12]. So, Sr promoted catalyst can induce both more CO2 interaction and enhanced C-H dissociation [13]. After getting a potential catalyst, the industry relies on process optimization to maximize the catalytic performance. The optimization of DRM, along with other chemical and physical processes, has been significantly advanced through the employment of Response Surface Methodology (RSM). RSM stands out for its simplicity, flexibility, and robustness, enabling the identification and quantification of both significant and insignificant factors and their interactions. It simplifies the assessment of input parameters' impact on the response, offering a streamlined evaluation of their relative significance [14–17]. Parallelly, the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) methodology, a deep learning algorithm mimicking the human brain's structure and function, has shown remarkable precision and reliability. It surpasses RSM in modeling complex, nonlinear multivariate systems, evidenced by higher R2 values, F-tests, and lower error terms. The ANN's superiority in predictive capability and fault tolerance, especially in handling systems with a high degree of nonlinearity, underscores its potential for refining process optimization in various fields [18–21]. RSM and ANN have been extensively applied across several domains, evaluating process parameters' significance and investigating diverse process aspects without necessitating accurate system expressions or physical meanings. Their combined use has particularly highlighted ANN's dominance, offering more accurate predictions compared to RSM alone. This is attributed to ANN's comprehensive data utilization for response prediction, necessitating more extensive runs than RSM [14,22,23]. This omnipotence of ANN, alongside its ability to capture complex nonlinear relationships and perform intricate operations, has been validated in multiple studies across different applications—from predicting permeable concrete properties and Pavement Condition Index (PCI) accuracy to optimizing methane yield from palm oil mill effluent and forecasting the mechanical performance of recycled aggregate concretes [24–27]. Further illustrating ANN's versatility and superiority, [21] demonstrated that ANN models notably outperform traditional Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) in predicting the properties of pervious concrete blended with Ground Granulated Blast-furnace Slag. This positions ANN as an effective alternative for accurately forecasting material strength and permeability. Additionally, ANN's capability extends to multi-variable regression models (MVR), outshining conventional models in predicting the unconfined compressive strength of expansive soil amended with bagasse ash and lime, as shown by [28]. In a distinct application, [29] introduced a model predictive control (MPC) for a Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) biomass control system, leveraging the radial basis function (RBF) in ANN for enhanced control performance. Their findings revealed that RBFNN-based MPC outperforms the traditional state space model-based MPC, attributing this to ANN's dynamic monitoring capabilities over static models. Similarly [30], observed that ANNs provide a more effective approach for predicting the fatigue life of riveted joints in AA2024 aluminum alloy plates compared to analytical or numerical methods, highlighting the method's adaptability to complex engineering challenges. The application of RSM and ANN in simulating the petroleum refining process further underscores their utility, with researchers successfully employing these methodologies to predict the properties of various compositions of Iraqi oil [18]. This widespread adoption and success of ANN can be attributed to its remarkable fault tolerance, ability to model complex nonlinear relationships, and ability to execute sophisticated operations, especially beneficial in systems characterized by significant nonlinearity[16,18,31–33]. Ayodele et al. employed the ANN model to investigate the effect of partial pressure, CH4:CO2 ratio (feed ratio) and temperature over catalytic activity over ceria-supported cobalt catalyst [34]. By using RSM, the optimum reaction conditions are predicted over Ta-promoted Ni/ZSM-5, Dendritic fibrous type SBA-15-supported Ni catalyst, activated carbon-supported cobalt catalyst and NieCo/MgO-ZrO2 catalysts [35–38]. Izhab et al. achieved optimum response of H2-yield (82.9) and CO-yield (59%) at 903 °C, 0.88 bar, 1.31 feed ratio and 4.488 L/h.g GHSV over activated carbon-supported cobalt catalyst [37]. The close experimental results (86% H2 yield and 53.8% CO yield) validate the authenticity of the RSM model. This study pioneers the comprehensive evaluation of Response Surface Methodology (RSM) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN) techniques, specifically employing Radial Basis Function Neural Networks (RBFNN), for optimizing the dry reforming of methane using a novel 5Ni+3Sr/10Zr+Al catalyst composition. Unlike previous research, this work integrates extensive experimental data [39] to compare the predictive accuracies of RSM and ANN, leveraging determination coefficients (R2), F ratios, and a suite of error analysis parameters. Through the application of second-order regression models, validated by meticulous ANOVA testing, we not only establish but also rigorously test a three-layered Feed Forward Neural Network coupled with the Radial Basis Function. This innovative approach enables a nuanced investigation into the effects of input variables across both three and two-dimensional spaces, culminating in the precise identification of optimal reaction conditions. Our findings not only underscore the enhanced predictive capabilities and efficiency of ANN, particularly RBFNN, over traditional RSM in chemical process optimization but also introduce a robust framework for the application of these methodologies in catalysis and chemical engineering. This study sets a new benchmark for methodological precision and depth in the field, paving the way for future investigations into catalytic process optimization and modeling. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material 10 %ZrO2-Al2O3 (purchased from Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co. Ltd.), Ni (NO3)2·6H2O (98 %, Alfa Aesar) and Sr(NO3)2 (98 %, Alfa Aesar) 2.2 Catalyst preparation The support 10 %ZrO2-Al2O3 (purchased from Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co. Ltd.) is made up of 9.72 wt% ZrO2 and 90.28 wt% alumina. It has 126 m2/g specific surface area, and 50 % of the support particles are smaller than 60.3 μm (D50 = 60.3 μm). 5 wt% Ni (NO3)2·6H2O (Equivalent to 5wt% Ni) is dissolved in 10 ml distilled water, and then after, Sr(NO3)2 (equivalent to 3 wt% Sr) is added to this solution. Lastly, the support 10 %ZrO2-Al2O3 is added into the solution under stirring conditions. The solution is heated and agitated until a slurry is formed. The slurry is dried in the oven at 120 °C and then calcined at 600 °C (at 3 °C/min heating ramp) for 3 hours. Subsequently, the prepared catalysts were ground into powder. The support and catalyst are abbreviated as ZrAl and NiSrZrAl. The elemental composition of the NiSrZrAl catalyst is analyzed by Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra (Fig. S1). After discarding the oxygen, the elemental composition of Sr, Ni, Zr and Al is found to be 3.6 wt%, 5.4 wt%, 13.8 wt% and 68.2 wt%, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The NiSrZrAl catalyst is characterized with surface area and porosity and, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The detailed descriptions of the catalyst characterization techniques are included in the supplementary information S2. The NiSrZrAl has a type IV adsorption isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of ordered mesopores [40] (Fig. S3 A). With respect to support ZrAl, the specific surface area of the catalyst is decreased marginally (123 m2/g). For such an isotherm, a desorption branch is recommended for pore volume and pore size calculation [41]. dV/dlogW vs W plot (V is pore volume and W is pore width) shows a monomodal pore size distribution of size 18.5 nm (Fig. S 3B). H2-TPR result indicates moderate and strong interaction of NiO with support, which tends to reduce under H2 at intermediate temperature range and high-temperature range (> 600 °C) [42] (Fig. S 3C). A small shoulder peak of about 750 °C was also observed, which indicates the presence of reducible SrCO3 species [43]. SrCO3 species is formed by the interaction of Sr+2 and CO2 over the catalyst [43]. CO2-temperature programmed desorption result shows a diffuse peak of weak basic sites by surface hydroxyl (at 100 °C) and intense peak of moderate strength basic sites by surface oxide (at ∼300 °C) [44] (Fig. S 3D). Apart from these, diffuse peaks for “surface bond CO2-interacting species” (at 625 °C) and “Sr+2 bond CO2 species” (at 800 °C) are also observed, which are attributed to strong basic sites [45,46]. Overall, it can be said that after bearing Ni and Sr over ZrAl support, the surface area of the catalyst is marginally decreased, NiSrZrAl has a wide range of basic sites (from weak to strong), and it bears adequate active sites “Ni” which is under moderate and strong interaction with support. 2.4 Catalyst activity test 0.1 g catalyst was packed in a tubular stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (PID Eng & Tech, 9 mm I.D.) equipped with a K-type thermocouple for temperature monitoring. Catalyst is pre-reduced by H2 (flow rate 30 mL/min for 1 h) at 800 °C and then DRM reaction was carried out in the following operating conditions: 600 °C to 750 °C reaction temperatures, 12,000 cm3g−1h−1 to 42,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocities, and 0.5–1 CH4/CO2 ratios. The DRM gas feed is composed of CH4, CO2 and N2, where the flow of nitrogen is fixed at 10 ml/min in all runs. The product is analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a proper Q column, molecular sieve columns, and a thermal conductivity detector. After 90 min on stream, the experimental CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion and H2/CO ratio were calculated (as shown below). The final value is taken by averaging the value of three consecutive readings. C H 4 conversion ( % ) = C H 4 in − C H 4 out C H 4 in × 100 C O 2 conversion ( % ) = C O 2 in − C O 2 out C O 2 in × 100 H 2 CO = moles of H 2 produced moles of CO produced 3 Process optimization 3.1 Response surface methodology (RSM) Response surface methodology is an empirical modeling technique used to estimate the relationship between the set of controllable experimental factors and the observed results [47]. RSM is a resourceful tool that is conjured up with mathematical and statistical techniques for designing experiments and building models utilized in the analysis of engineering issues. It is also useful for evaluating the effects of variables besides investigating the interactive effects between several factors at different levels, powerful for reducing the complexity of problems and solving multivariate equations concurrently in addition to searching for the optimum conditions of variables to predict targeted responses as well as the evaluation of the most influential factors on chosen responses [48]. RSM is efficient in dealing with the limitations of the conventional method of one factor at a time besides being suitable for problems in which there is no exact relationship between controllable input independent variables and the obtained response outlets with a minimum number of experiments [49–52]. To eliminate the effect of different units and ranges in the experimental domain, to allow the parameters of a different magnitude to be investigated more evenly, and to establish the proper experimental design to be performed, the actual values of the process variables should be codified to be in the range of –1 and +1, employing the following Eq: [53–56]. (1) coded value = actual value − mean value half of range Actual and coded values for the process parameters are presented in Table (1) . The mathematical model expressed in terms of coded variables is useful for identifying the relative impact of the factors by comparing the factor coefficients [57]. Response Surface Method (RSM) has been established through a second-order equation of the following form via multiple regression techniques to fit the functional relationships between the coded independent and dependent variables while the robustness of data fitting is inspected by analysis of variance (ANOVA) [17,53,55,56]: (2) Y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 k β i X i + ∑ i = 1 k − 1 ∑ j = i + 1 k β ij X i X j + ∑ i = 1 k β i X i 2 + ɛ where, Y is the response variable; X i and X j are the input coded values of the variables that affect the response variable and ɛ represents the random error or uncertainties between predicted and measured values, k is the number of variables, and β 0 , β i , β ii and β ij are the regression constants of intercept, linear, quadratic and interaction terms, respectively. The following Eq. (3) has been advocated to represent the response surface of conversion or formation of the various components as a function of the coded input variables. (3) Y = β 0 + β SV * X SV + β T * X T + β Rt * X Rt + β SV * T * X SV * X T + β T * Rt X T * X Rt + β T * R t 2 * X T * X Rt 2 + β SV 2 * X SV 2 + β T 2 * X T 2 + β T 3 * X T 3 Multiple regression techniques employing Eq. (3) has been applied to the experimental data cited in Table (1) by means of Microsoft Excel 2010 and Matlab 9.0 to establish the relationships between the coded independent and dependent variables. Details of all these concepts have been dealt with in the papers of [58–62]. The resulting predictive models for the various responses are as follows: For CH4 conversion: (4) Y = C H 4 = 64.31 − 12.85 * X SV + 27.39 * X T − 7.609 * X Rt + 2.692 * X SV * X T − 6.148 * X T * X Rt 2 − 6.912 * X T 3 For CO2 conversion: (5) Y = C O 2 = 57.67 − 6.956 * X SV + 17.96 * X T + 7.915 * X Rt + 5.410 * X T * X Rt For H 2 / CO molar ratio: (6) Y = H 2 / CO = 0.8023 − 0.0887 * X SV + 0.0583 * X T + 0.0810 * X Rt + 0.0288 * X SV * X T + 0.0602 * X SV 2 − 0.0340 * X T 2 The large F-values and small Significance F values in Table (2) signify the validation of the above polynomial equation models for all terms within a 95 % confidence interval [18,63]. These regression equations can precisely predict the true response surface well [64,65]. The R2 and adj-R2 values ≥ 0.9 beside the negligible difference between them in addition to the agreement between the “ R pred 2 ” values with the corresponding “ R adj 2 ” (difference < 0.2) indicates the real and good relations between the independent and dependent variables for the various components of the reaction system [17,32,56,66]. The adequate precision values of (> 4) show good model discernment, and each of these models could be used to traverse the design space [56,67–69]. The values of CV < 10 indicate the great degree of precision with which experiments were performed [70,71] The evidence for the validity of the regression models and their high capability to forecast the response has been affirmed by comparing the experimental data and the corresponding predicted ones recorded in Table (1) beside the parity plots of Fig. 2 (a)–(c) as the data points on the plot were reasonably clustered around the diagonal [72–74]. Only the values of the significant coefficients of the cited Eq. (3) along with the related low values of p < (α = 0.05) and Standard Error beside ǀt-statǀ and % P i _ eff are recorded in Table (3) , indicating the validity of the model equations [16,63]. The larger the magnitude of the t-value, P i _ eff and the smaller the p-value, the more significant is the corresponding coefficient [74,75]. The empty cells belong to the omitted non-significant coefficients. The positive sign of the model terms indicates the synergistic effect of temperature for the conversion of CH4 & CO2, while the negative sign of the space velocity indicates its antagonistic effect. Increasing the CH4:CO2 mole ratio decreases the CH4 conversion but increases the CO2 conversion. The effect of the process parameters on the conversion of CH4 & CO2 is of the order of temperature > space velocity > CH4:CO2 mole ratio. This is indicated by comparing the values of the coefficients, |tStat|, P-value & P eff . As for the H2/CO mole ratio, it increases with the increase of temperature and CH4:CO2 mole ratio and decrease of space velocity. The effect of the operating conditions is of the order of space velocity > CH4:CO2 mole ratio > temperature. 3.2 Artificial neural network (ANN) Artificial neural networks (ANNs) are highly versatile and scalable tools that can be used to model and analyze complex relations to offer excellent correlations resolving inadequately formalized or in_formalized task results used across the globe [25,76]. ANN, since its introduction as a universal function approximator [77,78], has dominated machine learning and artificial intelligence due to its capability to learn from previous events and its general structure to specify the relationship between input parameters and output responses without the need to specify the affiliation among variables or relevant mathematical equations beside its ability to approximate any function and capturing nonlinear and complex interactions among variables in a system where the accuracy and flexibility offered by ANN are quite impressive guaranteed to reach the accuracy of cumbersome regression models which use significant computing resources during operation [55,79–82]. ANN is a massive structure of interconnected networks of supervised deep learning algorithms based on a simplified analogy to the behavior of the human brain to mimic the pattern of processing information through a large number of interlinked units called neurons arranged in layers [19,83]. Each neuron is a mathematical function that collects, classifies information and produces an output. ANN algorithms have emerged for modeling resilient and nonlinear systems, predicting more precise and accurate results compared to RSM [84,85]. Many characteristics exhibited by artificial neural networks, such as nonlinearity, large scale, strong parallel processing ability, fault tolerance, as well as robustness and strong self-learning ability make it attractive for fault detection and diagnosis in complex systems. They are widely used in chemical and engineering processes, complex systems, industrial processes, catalyst optimization design, reaction optimization, Optimal Design of Reactors and process control [31,32,86]. 3.2.1 Radial basis function The radial Basis Function (Fig. S4), originally established by [87] as a universal approximator similar to the Gaussian density function, enjoying the best approximation property among all feed-forward networks, works on the principle of function approximation to fit irregular topographic contours of geographical data of both deterministic and stochastic response functions [88]. 3.2.2 Radial basis function neural networks (RBFNNs) An RBFNN (Fig. S5, Fig. S6) is a “supervised” learning method network having three layers of neurons: a hidden radial basis layer of S1 RADBAS neurons, an output linear layer of S2 PURELIN neurons (that represents and is equal to the response of the system besides), and an input layer with a number of neurons represents and is equal to the independent variables of the system to feed their values to each of the neurons in the hidden layer without performing any processing. RBFNN can fit any function satisfactory to any desired accuracy with correct weight to modify the signal carried from one node to the other and either enhance or diminish the influence of the specific connection beside bias value, allowing the sensitivity of the radbas neuron to be attuned [88–94]. The Details of RBFNNs are described in Supplementary Information S7). Radial Basis Function and Model are commonly employed in several fields with high accuracy for the interpolation of scattered data in high dimensions as they can deal with the regularity that is difficult to analyze in the system. This is due to their simple structure and implementation, strong ability for nonlinear function approximation, not having the problem of local minima, fast convergence to optimum solution, strong tolerance to input noise, aptitude to adapt to online learning and ease to configure via simple nature of the three-layer architecture [88–93]. RBFNNs are widely used in the control and optimization of distillation tower, fault diagnosis, image recognition, chemical process optimization, prediction of physical properties of compounds, optimization of CO2 mass transfer flux, suitable for the control of nonlinear and time-varying dynamic systems, as function approximators in control system design and for quantitative structure-property relationship model (QSPR) to predict the properties of compounds or mixtures due to their approximating capabilities and compensation for complex disturbances and model uncertainties [86,95,96]. Prior to performing modeling of the reaction tests, various Radial Basis Function ANN configurations were tested in terms of the SSE and R2 to determine the model with the best performance by varying the hidden neurons from 1 to 20. This was done to avoid over-fitting and reduction in the convergence rate associated with large numbers or small numbers of neurons, respectively [54,75]. The best performance of the Radial Basis Function ANN models was obtained for the 3–10–1 topology. Details of all concepts of ANN & RBFNNs have been dealt with in previous papers[59]. 3.3 Assessment of the predictive capability RSM and ANN models Many methodologies cited in the literature for assessment of the goodness of models fitting for RSM & ANN methods besides error analyses, as presented in supplement S2, have been employed in this study, and the results are recorded in Tables (4: a-c) . The results revealed that the ANN is highly effective in response prediction compared to the RSM model in all aspects, with superior reliability and accuracy with better alignment of the experimental and predicted values. This is conveyed in the very high values of the R 2 & F ratio and the exceedingly low value of error indicators for the ANN results compared to that of RSM ones. Similar observations were obtained by many research groups studying various engineering problems, as revealed earlier in this study. The values of R adj 2 are (0.9924, 0.9723, 0.89193) in the case of RSM compared to the values of 1.00 in the case of ANN, and of F_ratio in the case of RSM are (322.82, 238.2, 38.14) matched to the (6.89E+30, 1.94E+31, 6.89E+30) in case of ANN for C H 4 , C O 2 conversion & H 2 /CO mole ratio respectively, entitling the superiority of ANN in prediction. Also, in all cases studied, the range of m a x e r r o r % & A D C m a x % for ANN are 2.18E-14 - 3.08E-14 & 0.0 - 1.54E-14, while those for RSM are 4.4751- 6.9282 & 0.7592 - 3.9371. Moreover, the values RMSE & MAPE for ANN are 1.28E-16 - 1.22E-14 & 1.00E-14 – 1.54E-14, whereas those for RSM are 0.0345 - 2.7690 & 1.6734 – 3.853 respectively as depicted in Table (4:b). These results designate an excellent generalization prediction capacity of ANN than that of the RSM. The greater modelling competence of ANN can be attributed to its universal approximation facility for nonlinearity, whereas RSM is only limited to a second-order polynomial regression (Shafi et al., 2018). Table (4:c) presents the relevancy factor RF , which reflects the effect of the independent variables on the response. The positive relevancy factor of R F Temp (0.4721- 0.8567) indicates the prominent effect of the increase of temperature towards the increase of CH4 & CO2 conversion and H2/CO ratio in agreement with [14,97]. Increase in CH4:CO2 mole ratio R F Rt , decreases CH4 conversion ( R F Rt = − 0.35 ) and increases both CO2 conversion R F Rt = 0.35 and H2/CO mole ratio R F Rt = 0.46 . Increase of space velocity decreases both CH4 & CO2 conversion and decreases H2/CO mole ratio, ( R F SV = − 0.5866 : -0.3520). These results agree with those obtained with RSM.Table (4:a) reveals that the ANN method is more expensive than RSM. This is shown in the larger elapsed time for NN (8.3396 - 8.8259 sec) compared to that of RSM (0.1776 - 0.5995 sec) because the ANN method performs a series of computationally expensive function evaluations for a single model. 4 Simulation and optimization Graphical demonstration of results through three-D (3D) surface and contour plots represent endlessness of combinations between two variables while the third variable is kept constant. These plots envisage and interpret the nature of the synergetic relationship and mutual interaction between two combined experimental parameters and the response in a clarified view. The contour plot echoed the important influence of various factors interacting with the overall evaluation. The steeper the curve, the greater the widespread processing conditions [18,67,68,75,98]. Matlab 9.0 has been utilized to estimate the concentration of the various components of the reaction system and to accomplish the response surface plots for the predicted components. Eqs. 4-6 have been exploited for the RSM plots, while for the ANN method, the final optimum architecture was utilized. This has been accomplished by dividing each factor into 20 intervals and carrying out the simulation versus two coded variables while keeping the third at zero coded value. Therefore, a total of 400 situations were evaluated. The simulation results are exposed in Figs. 3, 4 and 5 for RSM & Figs. 6, 7 and 8 for the ANN method, along with the experimental data. The maximum response concentration and its corresponding input variables for RSM & ANN methods, as depicted in Table (5) , have been achieved by grid search exploring the simulated results of the entire region defined by the experimental design limits. 5 Comparative appraisal of RSM and ANN RSM has the facility to diagnose, itemize and evaluate significant and insignificant factors and their interactions based on their involvement in response estimation besides performing precise sensitivity analysis. ANN is more rigorous, truthful and responsible compared to RSM superior for sophisticated, complex nonlinear multivariate models because of its unexpected capability in simulating the nonlinear relation between the variables and response by the iterative training process. ANN has a higher prophetic power compared with RSM, which is only applied to quadratic estimation. However, the ANN model offers little information about the participation of the factors and their influence on the response if further analysis has not been done[14,32,72,99]. For testing the resilience and long life of the catalyst, the stability test of the Ni-Sr-Zr-Al catalyst is performed for 20 h time on stream using the optimum conditions as 1:1 CH4/CO2 gas feed ratio, 750 °C reaction temperature, 12,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity. The activity results in terms of CH4 conversion, CO2 conversion and H2/CO is presented in Fig. 9 . The H2/CO ratio is 1, which remains invariant during 20 h time on stream, whereas CH4 conversion and CO2 conversion varies slightly from 87 to 85 % and from 91 to 87 % respectively. The high conversion (>85 %) and constant H2/CO ratio (equal to 1) up to 20 h time on stream indicates the industrial suitability of the NiSrZrAl catalyst. 6 Conclusion This study aims to optimize methane dry reforming through Response Surface Methodology (RSM) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN) models, focusing on the influence of operational parameters such as temperature, CO2:CH4 mole ratio, and space velocity on the system's efficiency. Utilizing second-order quadratic models, the RSM analysis demonstrated commendable predictive accuracy, reflected in high F-values, adequate precision, R2, and adjusted R2 values, all exceeding 0.9. This precision underscores the models' capability to accurately predict the system's behavior within the tested parameters, highlighting their relevance for new experimental conditions. In parallel, a robust and finely tuned artificial neural network model incorporating a radial basis function with ten neurons was developed, trained, and rigorously validated against experimental data. This model's predictions outshone the RSM's in accuracy, showcasing superior performance through elevated R2 and F-ratios and minimal error margins. Such findings attest to the ANN model's exceptional predictive power and reliability, especially in capturing the nonlinear dynamics of the catalytic reforming process. The investigative approach of both RSM and ANN elucidated the significant role temperature plays in enhancing methane and CO2 conversion rates. Furthermore, simulations conducted across the spectrum of input variables yielded a comprehensive depiction of the optimal conditions conducive to maximizing reaction efficiency, as corroborated by experimental data. These simulations, rendered in both three-dimensional and two-dimensional perspectives, offer invaluable insights into the synergetic interactions between operational parameters and their collective impact on the catalytic reforming process. NiSrZrAl catalyst outperformed with > 85 % CH4 and CO2 conversion with H2/CO ∼1 up to 20 h time on stream at optimum operating conditions (1 CH4/CO2,750 °C reaction temperature, 12,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity). In essence, this study not only underscores the pivotal contributions of RSM and ANN in advancing our understanding of methane dry reforming but also illuminates the path forward for optimizing such catalytic processes. Through precise modeling and simulation, we unveil the nuanced interplay of variables that govern the reaction dynamics, setting a benchmark for future research in catalytic process optimization. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the molecular dynamics of methane dry reforming catalyzed by a novel nickel-strontium-zirconium-aluminum (5Ni+3Sr/10Zr+Al) catalyst, leveraging both Response Surface Methodology (RSM) and Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN) for predictive optimization. Focusing on the impact of operational parameters—hourly space velocity, reaction temperature, and CO2:CH4 mole ratio—on the conversion rates and formation of reaction components, we aim to predict optimal conditions and corresponding process variables. Through a comparison of a three-layer Feed Forward Neural Network, optimized at a 3:10:1 topology, with traditional RSM approaches, our findings highlight the superior predictive capabilities of ANN models. Notably, ANN demonstrated exceptional performance with R adj 2 and F_Ratio values significantly surpass those of RSM, alongside lower statistical error terms. This superiority is attributed to ANN's robust handling of nonlinear relationships between inputs and outputs, asserting its potential for enhancing predictive accuracy in chemical process optimization. At optimum predicted conditions like 1 CH4/CO2,750 °C reaction temperature, 12000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity, NiSrZrAl outperformed with > 85 % CH4 and CO2 conversion with H2/CO ∼1 up to 20 h time on stream. Our research underscores the importance of integrating advanced modeling techniques for the efficient and accurate prediction of catalytic reactions, offering valuable insights for future applications in chemical engineering and catalysis.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced predictive optimization of methane dry reforming via ResponseSurface methodology and artificial neural network approaches: Insights using a novel nickel-strontium-zirconium-aluminum catalyst
